global_flags.description: which  interrogates  various  environment variables,  possibly  including $LC_MESSAGES and $LANG.  To temporarily override the determined value, use this option to supply a lo‐ cale string directly to whatis.  Note that it will not take effect until the search for pages actually begins.   Output  such  as  the help message will always be displayed in the initially determined locale.
Normally, output will be truncated to the terminal width to avoid ugly results from poorly- written NAME sections.

By default, whatis uses the $MANPATH environment vari‐ able,  unless  it  is empty or unset, in which case it will determine an appropriate manpath based on your $PATH environment variable. This option overrides the contents of $MANPATH.
If a name matches any part of a page name, a match will be  made.   This  option  causes whatis to be somewhat slower due to the nature of database searches.

list is a colon- or comma-separated list of sections.  If an entry in list is  a  simple  sec‐ tion,  for example "3", then the displayed list of descriptions will include pages in sections "3", "3perl", "3x", and so on; while if an entry in list has an extension, for example "3perl", then the list will only include pages in that exact part of  the  manual  sec‐ tion.
this  system  has access to other operating systems' manual page names, they can be accessed using this option.  To search NewOS's manual page names, use the option -m NewOS.

each  name  as  a pattern containing shell style wildcards.  For a match to be made, an expanded name must match the entire page name.  This option causes whatis to be somewhat slower due to the nature of database searches.
